definitions.definition: to put a lot of effort into making something successful or strong so that it will last

examples.text: a move to forge new links between management and workers
Strategic alliances are being forged with major European companies.
She forged a new career in the music business.
They forged a lead in the first 30 minutes of the game.

definitions.definition: to make an illegal copy of something in order to cheat people
definitions.labels: (British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(especially British English)(especially British English)(especially North American English)(especially British English)

examples.text: He's getting good at forging his mother's signature.
New digital techniques can spot paintings that have been forged.

definitions.definition: to shape metal by heating it in a fire and hitting it with a hammer; to make an object in this way
to move forward in a steady but powerful way

examples.text: He forged through the crowds to the front of the stage.
She forged into the lead *(= in a competition, race, etc.)*.

wordOrigin: verb senses 1 to 3 Middle English (also in the general sense ‘make, construct’): from Old French forger, from Latin fabricare ‘fabricate’, from fabrica ‘manufactured object, workshop’. The noun is via Old French from Latin fabrica. verb sense 4 mid 18th cent.: perhaps an aberrant pronunciation of force.
